Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story: The phone in my headset crackles as I scan the script for the hundredth time, my voice already hoarse from explaining the new service. Each prospect today seems to have a barrage of technical questions—details about data privacy, compatibility, hidden fees. The script only skims the surface, and my supervisor’s voice echoes in my mind: “Stick to the script, handle objections, don’t improvise.” I feel the pressure to keep the call times short and the conversion rates high. But my mind keeps drifting to my wallet, sitting on the kitchen counter at home. I need that ID to vote, and this morning is my only window to grab it before work swallows the rest of my week. The polls are open tomorrow, but I can’t risk another forgotten detail. My manager expects me to stay glued to my seat, but my civic duty tugs at me, reminding me of the importance of my vote. I stare at the clock, torn between the demands of my job and the responsibility of being a voter, anxiety tightening in my chest as I weigh which expectation I’ll have to let down.
